data.meta_description: Actress. She was a German-born actress of Jewish ancestry, who performed prolifically in Germany, France, England as well as the United States. Born Lilli Marie Peiser in Poznan, Germany, what was then Poland, she was one of three daughters of an actress and a physician. Changing her professional surname to Palmer, she...
data.text:
Actress. She was a German-born actress of Jewish ancestry, who performed prolifically in Germany, France, England as well as the United States. Born Lilli Marie Peiser in Poznan, Germany, what was then Poland, she was one of three daughters of an actress and a physician. Changing her professional surname to Palmer, she and her sister studied drama in Germany, and her sister, Irene Prador, became a successful actress. Her family fled Germany for France with the Nazi persecution of Jews. She appeared in an operetta at the Moulin Rouge in Paris before she made her screen debut in the British film ''Crime Unlimited'' in 1935. On January 25, 1943, she married actor Rex Harrison, moved to Hollywood, and appeared on Broadway in the play ''Bell, Book and Candle'', where she co-starred with Harrison. The couple had a son before their divorce in 1956. For feature films, she was most noted for starring in ''Cloak and Dagger'' in 1946, "Body and Soul" in 1947, "The Long Dark Hall" in 1951, and ''The Four Posters'' in 1952. After her divorce, she returned to Germany for films and was awarded the Deutscher Filmpreis for Best Actress for her portrayal of Anna Anderson in "The Story of Anastasia." She had a Golden Globe Award nomination for her performance in "But Not for Me" in 1959. She also had her own TV series, "The Lilli Palmer Show," in 1953. For the 1986 television miniseries "Peter the Great ", she earned another Golden Globe Award nomination. She married Argentine actor Carlos Thompson in 1957, and the couple stayed married until her death.

View burial memorial and family links here.
